crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects an office document with an embedded VBA project. While this is fairly common it is sometimes used for malicious intent.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: File With Uncommon Extension Created By An Office Application
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the creation of files with an executable or script extension by an Office application.
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Vadim Khrykov (ThreatIntel), Cyb3rEng (Rule), Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects a suspicious process spawning from one of the Microsoft Office suite products (Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Publisher, Visio, etc.)
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Markus Neis, FPT.EagleEye Team, Vadim Khrykov, Cyb3rEng, Michael Haag, Christopher Peacock @securepeacock, @scythe_io

match_context.values: @{Hashes=SHA1=CE1886E4C70A0C3258AE53179E61A21CD8E1F8ED,MD5=D5275B2E3776D4D04C390D7188B0F7AE,SHA256=91946B224CE17F0DAFA05235FB87478A3BA25A51FAC5AFE3C839682A6436ACB6,IMPHASH=DCDEE2FF2311B9AE7C4D768FA56524DD; CurrentDirectory=C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Root\Office16\; OriginalFileName=MSHTA.EXE; Product=Internet Explorer; Description=Microsoft (R) HTML Application host; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine="C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Root\Office16\EXCEL.EXE" /automation -Embedding; CommandLine=C:\Windows\System32\mshta.exe -Embedding; FileVersion=11.00.22621.2070 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\root\Office16\EXCEL.EXE; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\mshta.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects non-interactive PowerShell activity by looking at the "powershell" process with a non-user GUI process such as "explorer.exe" as a parent.

Detects modification of the registry settings used for Internet Explorer and other Windows components that use these settings. An attacker can abuse this registry key to add a domain to the trusted sites Zone or insert JavaScript for persistence

attributes.magic: Composite Document File V2 Document, Little Endian, Os: Windows, Version 6.2, Code page: 1252, Name of Creating Application: Microsoft Excel, Create Time/Date: Sat Sep 16 00:00:00 2006, Last Saved Time/Date: Tue Nov 25 05:47:53 2025, Security: 1

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
**  
The provided macros are primarily declarations of workbook and sheet attributes in a Microsoft Excel environment. Each macro is structured to define the properties of the respective sheets (ThisWorkbook, Sheet1, Sheet2, and Sheet3) without any executable code or functions that would indicate malicious behavior.

Key observations include:

1. **Attribute Declarations:** The macros consist solely of attribute declarations such as `VB_Name`, `VB_Base`, and other properties related to the workbook and sheets. These attributes are standard for defining the characteristics of an Excel object and do not perform any actions that could be deemed harmful.

2. **Lack of Executable Code:** There are no function definitions, subroutines, or any commands that would execute operations like file manipulation, network communication, or registry modifications. This absence of operational code suggests that these macros do not engage in any suspicious activities.

3. **No Indicators of Malicious Behavior:** The macros do not exhibit any signs of obfuscation, base64 decoding, persistence mechanisms, or attempts to manipulate security settings. They also lack any functionality that would typically be associated with malware, such as downloading files, executing programs, or altering system configurations.

4. **Decoy Comments or Strings:** While there are no comments present in the macros, even if they were included, the content analyzed does not suggest any intent to mislead or disguise malicious functionality.

In conclusion, based on the analysis of the macro behaviors and their structure, it can be determined that these macros are benign and do not pose any threat to the system.

The provided macros consist solely of default attribute declarations for ThisWorkbook and several Sheet objects. No executable code, such as subroutines or functions, is present within any of the modules. Consequently, these macros do not perform any operations, do not exhibit any suspicious behaviors, and do not contain any functionality that could be deemed malicious.
